Efficiently updating the Acceleration Structures (AS) for scenes with hundreds or thousands of objects, each with complex geometry, can be a challenging task. However, there are several techniques that can be used to improve performance:

1. Use a hierarchy of AS: Instead of using a single AS for the entire scene, you can create a hierarchy of AS where each AS represents a subset of the scene. This can be achieved using techniques such as bounding volume hierarchies (BVH) or octrees. Updating the AS for a small subset of the scene is faster than updating a single AS for the entire scene.
2. Use AS update flags: Vulkan provides update flags that can be used to selectively update parts of the AS that have changed. This can be useful when only a small subset of objects in the scene have moved or changed.
3. Use AS instance transformation: Instead of updating the geometry in the AS, you can use instance transformation to transform the objects in the scene. This allows you to update the transformation matrix associated with each object without rebuilding the AS. However, this approach may not be suitable for scenes with highly dynamic objects.
4. Use multi-threading: Updating the AS can be a computationally intensive task, but it can be parallelized using multi-threading. Vulkan provides several synchronization mechanisms, such as fences and semaphores, that can be used to coordinate work across multiple threads.
5. Use AS build flags: Vulkan also provides build flags that can be used to optimize the construction of the AS. For example, you can use build flags to minimize memory usage, improve build time, or improve AS performance.

By combining these techniques, you can efficiently update the AS for scenes with hundreds or thousands of objects, each with complex geometry. However, the most suitable approach depends on the specific requirements and characteristics of your application.
